  2570. After trying to cut my 2 year old's hair (with scissors) so many times and always ending up with an awful hack job, I gave in and decided to find a decent pair of clippers. I really love these clippers. I can cut my son's hair in minutes flat. It came with a lot of pieces... various lengths, special edge trimmers, nice scissors, and two different kinds of combs. Not to mention equipment/oil to clean the trimmer with, when needed.<br /><br />Really my only complaint is --- this thing is LOUD. Seriously loud. I think it's louder than my vacuum. It freaked my son out a bit the first time I used it (and me too, to be honest), but now he's used to it and will play on my phone while I cut his hair. I still haven't used the special around the ear trimming pieces because I can barely get near his ears with this thing. In part I think it's the volume of these clippers (did I mention they are LOUD?), but it's mostly that my son hates to have his ears touched. He's incredibly ticklish.<br /><br />I thought this was an amazing price for a really nice high quality and seemingly heavy duty product!<br /><br />One of the best things I've purchased from Amazon. Once my twin boys get old enough to start getting haircuts, I'm definitely going to be saving so much money cutting their hair. And, they will have cute hair cuts! No more horrible uneven bangs. I feel a little bad for when my son grows up and looks back at his pictures of those horrible, horrible cuts one day. At least I only attempted to cut his hair for a few months before buying these.. :)<br /><br />In a nutshell -- Awesome! LOUD.

  2586. I've only used these clippers one time, so I'll update this review in the future, but so far I am very impressed!<br /><br />They have a heft to them so that they don't feel cheap, while not being too cumbersome or heavy.<br /><br />I have very thick hair (almost every time I've ever gone to get my hair cut, the barber has noted how thick it is), and have had trouble with clippers in the past not easily cutting through my hair. Well, that is a thing of the past! These clippers cut through my hair like butter. No resistance whatsoever, no tugging/pulling of my hair, just cutting. I cut the bulk of my hair in 5 minutes (then spent time trimming). Love these clippers! During use they never got excessively warm or hot.<br /><br />The box isn't anything special, but does hold the clippers. The comb attachments don't have any separate compartment and I was worried about them breaking, so I grabbed an old electric razor leather case and placed them all in there, and then put that leather case in the plastic case next to the clippers. I feel much better about them now!<br /><br />I bought these for $17.99 and don't see how you could get a much better value than these for as well as they work (assuming they are durable and last). If you're looking for a set of inexpensive clippers, these seem like great ones to grab.

  2603. WAHL COLOR PRO 20 PIECE COMPLETE HAIR CUTTING KIT<br /><br />This kit comes with eight color coded guide combs to cut hair from one-eighth inch to one inch long. The cutter blades are very sharp and are self-sharpening. My husband gets a nice, clean, even cutting without any pulling of the hair on his head or his beard. All of these accessories are contained in a light weight plastic case for easy storage.<br /><br />The kit also included left and right ear taper combs, ear trim guide, brush, comb, and oil.<br /><br />The instructions that are included is a large fold out ten step pictorial that makes the hair cutting procedures very clear.<br /><br />My husband is in his sixties and is of the age where his hair has thinned on top. Now he can do his own buzz cut with the number two comb and it looks perfect. He also used the number one comb on his beard and moustache area - both he wears close to his skin, neither is long. Now he can cut his own hair any time he wants to and it only takes him about ten minutes.<br /><br />This WAHL is a great product -- built right, has every accessory necessary for any type of shaving/trimming/cutting, and the price is right. Add this to the savings of not having to go to the barber shop and being able to trim your hair at your own personal convenience, and you have a win/win situation.<br /><br />This is an awesome little kit and one that we are glad that we purchased.<br /><br />Thank you.

  2666. I just rate the product at average score of it, since my review is not actually review. It is an information to whom who are planning to use it in 220V country. I thought I would use it with 220V to 110V converter but realized that it is not the solution. Without proper conversion 50Hz to 60Hz it is extremely loud and shaky. Just converting 220 to 110V is not sufficient. You would need 220V 50Hz to 110V 60Hz converter which costs at least 150 bucks.

  2730. Provides a nice clean cut.
  2731. I am not a barber but I do cut my own hair as well as my friends' hair, and have had cheaper clippers which have been lost or broken, or thrown away in frustration over poor quality. I have seen reviews here stating that these Wahl clippers suffer from a variety of quality related defects. In my case it is just the opposite. No, I don't work for Wahls or know anyone who does, to make that clear, I'm just offering my personal opinion.<br /><br />The pair of clippers I got are very nice. I never use scissors, only clippers like these. I have bought clippers five times before, these Wahls are either the nicest or are tied for it. The Wahls website includes video instruction which are clear, short and simple. Once you have the confidence, cutting hair is a simple task, made nearly idiot proof and so cheap as to boggle the mind. I've saved hundreds of dollars personally, and thousands if friends and family are included over time. At $15 a cut, 12 cuts per year, it's $180 a year per person, call it near $10,000 over a lifetime. That's a lot of hair. Owning clippers makes this as easy as picking money up off the ground. Would you bend over and pick up $10,000? Then reach down and click your mouse...<br /><br />These are very well made clippers. They are heavy and feel solid in the hand. They are quite obviously designed for serious use. They feel warm and solid in my hand, humming away with a low, steady tone. A great feature in these clippers is the POWER screw in the side. People who complain about the noise either haven't ever used clippers or have a defective set or (probably) don't realize that this screw is there to address the issue of a poor or low current to the unit. Low power current results in a louder than expected buzzing sound. The screw is adjusted with a Phillips head and results in a quieter unit that is more efficient. It is an adjustment only found in high quality clippers, as it adds to the cost of making the clippers. The clipper housing is heavy gauge extruded plastic which can absorb the occasional drop, smack and fumble. I've mentioned owning clippers before. Common problems are a cheap, plasticky feel, lack of heft so it feels like you are holding a squirt gun not a tool, and poor or dull cutting teeth which can rip or tear hair not cut it cleanly. Cheap clippers also break over time. None of these problems afflict my Wahl clippers, though I see complaints about them elsewhere.<br /><br />This set comes in a clamshell plastic box which contains a color coded set of guides, which is very nice as the guides are commonly all black. They identify length by number, #1 being shortest at 1/8th of an inch, #8 longest at an inch. Ear guides are handy and clearly labeled for left and right ears. Oddly, eyebrow guides are included, for the hobbits among us. The colored guides are a handy system that prevents confusion. The color key is added to the clipper body so you can glance at your hand to see both the color of the clipper guide on the unit and the length the color printed on the clippers.<br /><br />The set includes cleaning brush, comb, clippers, guides, oil (nice touch as a small amount prevents an additional purchase until it runs out) and scissors all held together in a clamshell plastic box with clips to hold it securely shut. The box has enough room to hold everything and not get frustrated trying to cram it all in. It would benefit a lot from the addition of a single item, a cape to prevent hair from getting all over your clothes. If this was included I would have given 5 stars as it would represent that thoughtful addition that demonstrates the manufacturer provides not just what is required but offers the consideration that goes that extra distance which separates a good value from the perfect purchase.<br /><br />I hope this review helps you in your decision.housing is heavy gauge extruded plastic which can absorb the occasional drop, smack and fumble. I've mentioned owning clippers before. Common problems are a cheap, plasticky feel, lack of heft so it feels like you are holding a squirt gun not a tool, and poor or dull cutting teeth which can rip or tear hair not cut it cleanly. Cheap clippers also break over time. None of these problems afflict my Wahl clippers, though I see complaints about them elsewhere.<br /><br />This set comes in a clamshell plastic box which contains a color coded set of guides, which is very nice as the guides are commonly all black. They identify length by number, #1 being shortest at 1/8th of an inch, #8 longest at an inch. Ear guides are handy and clearly labeled for left and right ears. Oddly, eyebrow guides are included, for the hobbits among us. The colored guides are a handy system that prevents confusion. The color key is added to the clipper body so you can glance at your hand to see both the color of the clipper guide on the unit and the length the color printed on the clippers.<br /><br />The set includes cleaning brush, comb, clippers, guides, oil (nice touch as a small amount prevents an additional purchase until it runs out) and scissors all held together in a clamshell plastic box with clips to hold it securely shut. The box has enough room to hold everything and not get frustrated trying to cram it all in. It would benefit a lot from the addition of a single item, a cape to prevent hair from getting all over your clothes. If this was included I would have given 5 stars as it would represent that thoughtful addition that demonstrates the manufacturer provides not just what is required but offers the consideration that goes that extra distance which separates a good value from the perfect purchase.<br /><br />I hope this review helps you in your decision.
  2732. bought these because older set broke. works great. love the color coded guards and carrying case. helps keep everything organized.
  2733. For less than the price of a singular hair cut, I can now have my hair cut for life! My wife now cuts my hair, and does an impeccable job of it. The clippers are much better than the others we used to have, which broke. They are quiet, powerful, and cut as smooth as silk. Seriously, not one snag the entire time. I have thick hair that grows with a mind of it's own and usually get multiple pulls and snags, but not with these. Love the carrying case to keep everything organized. Ad definitely love the corded ones, as our last pair that were cordless didn't have the same power as these, and the cut wasn't as consistent. If the cord it too short, get and extension cord!
  2734. These are excellent clippers. If you are one of those people that believes weight is a sign of quality, then these are for you. They are not uncomfortably heavy by any means, but do have more weight than other clippers I have used before. The design fits very comfortably in your hand. They run very quietly and do not seem to get hot like other clippers do. I saw complaints in the reviews that the guard sizes were hard to read; they are not. You can see the guard size very easily, and just in case you cant, they are color coded. Each guard is a different color and on the clippers it has the size/color guide. I use them to shave my head and they cut nice and short. I also use them to trim my beard and they have never pulled the hair. They came very sharp and I am very happy with the purchase.

  2773. I've cut my own hair for the past 7 years with an older Wahl home clipper set that has worked exceptionally well, but as I'm now working overseas I wanted to have another set I could take with me and the price of this kit was too good to pass up. I was pleased with the overall construction and similar heft to our older model, and it seemed fine the first time I used it. The next time I needed to cut my hair I was overseas, and what had been a normal low buzz the first time had become a painfully loud racket - seriously loud enough to cause hearing damage over time.<br /><br />I suffered through that clip and stashed the kit until I came back home for a while and brought it along with me, thinking maybe the noise had something to do with needing to use a step-down voltage converter overseas. When I used it at home, though, it was still just as loud. Taking apart the blade assembly, I was able to ascertain that the noise had to do with the bar that's supposed to lock into the movable part of the blade. The part that locks into the blade is plastic and appears to be poorly constructed, such that it doesn't seat very well, resulting in a sort of rattle. Initially, I was able to push down on the blade and get it to stop for a while, but now that I'm back overseas again, I can't even get that to work.<br /><br />It's a shame, because I do think that it clips well otherwise, and I do like the assortment of attachments that come along with the kit. I would like to rate this product higher, but I will not use it again. I need my hearing for my work, and I'm not willing to risk damaging that. I'm in the market now for other, more reliable, options.

I use this to give myself a haircut/manscape once a week, yes my hair grows like weeds. i generally use it for about 15-20 minutes at a time and for what it is, it works great as long as you take care of it. after every few cuts i unscrew mine to clean the hair out, wipe out all the old oil and re apply new oil (which is provided in the kit). sure there are better products out there and i wish i had bought a wireless one because i dont have an outlet in my bathroom and i have to link extension cords together. the cord itself is not a bad length if you have an outlet in the bathroom though. if youre just casually cutting your hair once a month then go for it, great value. if you plan to use it often you might want to invest in something alot nicer. it does its job well
  2975. Great product and very cheap!

  2978. exessive noise, it's 0 I want a refund
  2979. I needed to replace the blades on my 12 year old Wahl clipper, which has run excellent from day one, being used twice a month since new. Replacement blades were about $12, this &#34;Color Pro&#34; clipper was $18 so I decided to &#34;upgrade&#34;. I assumed after 12+ years the quality might be even better, with improved ergonomics, and I liked the colored guides. Wrong. I'm assuming the motor is exactly the same, the sound is the same, vibrations are the same, and still gets warm/hottish in the same spot. I like the colored guides, but the quality of the plastics has taken a massive downturn. The clipper's side taper lever is so flimsy I cannibalized my old clipper's lever to replace the new one - very simple to make the swap but seriously disappointing. Even more alarming was the plastic in the accessories. The new hair comb design is exactly the same as my 12 year old one, but it says &#34;Made in USA&#34;. The new one says &#34;Made in China&#34;, and it shows some of the worst plastic tooling marks I have ever seen. And the new comb was more flimsy than a wet noodle - no exaggeration, it is unusable as it bends between your fingers! Instant garbage. In the end, this new &#34;Color Pro&#34; clipper is only an improvement over my 12 year old one because of the colored guide combs. Otherwise, disappointing that Wahl hasn't made any real improvements, and has obviously cut quality in the plastics.

  2991. Like you, I read various reviews before deciding on this Wahl to replace my old Oster that finally broke. (the two large ones). It's evident that the way they're all crammed into the hard case causes the tines to crack. Thankfully, my old oster guards fit so there isn't really a need to play the return return return game. The Wahl guards are a little thin in the tines compared to my oster guards. Clipper works well, just be prepared for possible broken guards.

My previous Wahl can cut through my thick hair like butter... this Wahl unfortunately does not have the same performance... I have a feeling that after a few more cuts to get my money's worth I will purchase a more powerful higher quality one... don't get me wrong - this one will do the job... but if you have thick hair and plan to use it to groom pets I suggest look elsewhere for a higher quaility and more powerful clipper...

  3064. I go to college in Evanston, IL and something I learned quickly this past freshman year was how expensive haircuts can be in the Chicago area. Haircuts at the cheapest are $20, without tip. That's a bit too much for me. I bought this Wahl set since I had a friend who also had a Wahl set that cut my hair a few times during the school year. It's summer time so I thought it'd be a perfect time for me to do a little experimenting myself!<br /><br />I bought the kit and then went on YouTube and watched a few videos about how to cut your own hair. Aaron Marino's video was especially helpful. After watching a few videos at least two times, I felt confident enough to go ahead and do it.<br /><br />Here's all you need:<br />Wahl haircutting kit<br />Hand mirror<br />Mirrors<br /><br />Essentially you always want to start with small cuts. Common sense right? So what I did was play it safe and started with a 7 going all the way around my sides and back. Then taking a 6, I went up to the middle part of my head, slightly above the top of the ear. With a 5, I went to about the middle of my ear. Essentially what this does is create a natural taper where it blends nicely since you started with the longer clipper going all the way around, and gradually got shorter as you moved down your head.<br /><br />After doing this I thought it was a bit too long still so I repeated the process going 5-4-3. Looked great. The toughest part I'd say is getting the back. What I found to be helpful was if I used my hand as a guide. So I'd look in the mirror using the hand mirror in one hand and shape with my hand that wasn't holding the clipper how the back would look. From there, your alternate hand serves as a \\"guard\\" against the clipper.<br /><br />Finally for the middle, this is really where you cut to your own liking. I pretty much mimicked what I'd seen my barber do several times where you take chuncks of your hair and kind of filter it between two fingers.<br /><br />Another tip I'd say is watch out when using the ear trim taper guards. If you aren't careful, you may find yourself with a bit too much hair taken off the mid area of your ear section. This slightly happened on my left side but it'll grow back. Honestly it wasn't that noticeable, but definitely be careful.<br /><br />All in all, a great product. Really easy to follow directions and combined with YouTube, just really easy to learn how to do. Skyped my parents a few days after and my Dad told me he wanted to cut his hair when I go home! Also received some compliments throughout the week. Friends were surprised when I mentioned I had cut it myself. Guess it turned out alright!<br /><br />Best part of all is that this kit pays for itself after one haircut. It's also quite a great skill to have because if you can cut your own hair, you can cut anyone's hair.<br /><br />Definitely recommend this product, the clippers are great and do a phenomenal job.
  3065. excellent haircutting, but the clippers is garbage

He even let me do a little manscaping on his back with it, and he definitely wouldn't have let me do that with his other set (TMI, I know, but it works great for that too). When I saw it was only $18, I had doubts, but it's nice quality, not flimsy at all. Buy it!

I can never remember who gets what #, but with the color-coding--luckily everybody has ended up with their favorite color being the right # for his hair. What a relief!<br /><br />The last one I bought (years ago, different brand) would *pull* hair instead of cutting. The boys would whimper & complain, & I finally quit using it. This one is much better--even my 5yo is happy to let me cut his hair.<br /><br />The case isn't awesome--it's close to impossible to get everything back in, & the first set I received had been broken because apparently, even the manufacturer couldn't do it. That is a definite plus in my family; as we all have a different grade of hair. My youngest has thick, fine hair, my oldest has a course grade of curly hair and my husband has hair somewhere in between. You do have to make sure that you take these apart and clean them periodically or they drag. In other words the guards will not comb through the hair as easily. I love the guards because: once you figure out which guard, for which head of hair, it is pretty easy sailing. These pay for themselves in the end, so I'll always keep a set around.<br />Hope that helps.

  3104. I was spending ten bucks on every haircut until I got this. Back then I was keeping my hair longer (not like Fabio or anything ... more like Rhett Butler in GWTW). But now I've gone back to something like Tom Cruise in Top Gun for the winter time and more of an Air Force cut in the summer.<br /><br />For the price of two haircuts I got this machine and not only am I saving money out the wazoo but I can have it cut once a month. (Believe me with an Air Force cut, once a month is a lot better anyway.)<br /><br />My wife was not happy about taking up cutting hair but my cut is simple (a single comb/guard in the winter, and a couple of guards for the summer) so there was a little resistance at first.<br /><br />About this particular machine, we were worried that for $20 it was going to be cheap and wouldn't last long. Wrong! This machine is extremely solid and feels like it will last forever. The kit comes with everything anybody would need and we didn't actually need any of it but the machine and less than half the guards but each buyer will use different pieces so having everything makes it perfect. The guards in this set are color coded so it makes using it very easy. There is even a color chart on the machine itself so picking the right guard is even simpler.<br /><br />We have not used this for girls' haircuts and aren't even contemplating it. Girls go to the hairdresser mostly for the gossip (at least around here anyway). ...Okay, I have to admit that I do miss talking about football, the crops/livestock/weather, and the local politics at the man-zone, err barber shop. But even if only one family member gets their hair cut with this machine it still saves a lot of money.

  3107. I had the clippers for a few days before I used it. The first thing that I shaved off was my (several inches long) winter beard. The clippers took it down to a 5 o'clock shadow before I thought I even got started. No scratches, nicks or skin irritation and I was easily able to shave the rest off with a regular razor.<br /><br />Next I attempted to cut my own hair per the instructions and did pretty well for a first time. I missed a few places on the top back of my head. My sister-in-law who uses this same brand of clippers to cut my brother and their kids hair finished it up and in time with practice I should be able to do it, although I suspect that the back of the neck will have to be finished by another person.<br /><br />I normally pay including tip $17 for a similar haircut at Fantastic Sam's. So with the next cut it will have more than paid for itself. It seems like it will last a long time. A small container of blade oil is included. In case anyone is wondering an [eye] brow trim guide is not included in this kit. An ear trim guide is included.

  3118. Around 10 years ago when mother nature decided that I no longer had any use for the majority of my hair... I no longer could justify going to a barber or \\"Supercuts\\" and paying $15 to $20 bucks plus tip for something I pretty much knew I could do myself and not mess up. So I purchased my first Wahl clipper and have been cutting my hair ever since. After 10 years of relatively no maintenance that first Wahl clipper died ... so I went on Amazon and purchase this one to replace the old one and have been absolutely satisfied with my purchase. Wahl has been making Clippers for many years.... it is a quality product that feels sturdy and well built and not cheap... I certainly didn't need all the other attachments that came with it... all I needed was the Clippers and the #1 attachment and two haircuts later it has paid for itself..... I really didn't think about it until I start writing this review... but before I started cutting my own hair, I figured I was getting my hair cut around 8 to 10 times a year... conservatively that's $200 per year +10 years = $2000... Wow... I wish everything I bought would bring me back such a return...this wasn't a purchase... it was an investment.

It comes with plenty of different size guides so that you get the right cut every time as well as hair cutting scissors, a comb and a guide on how to correctly cut hair. The first time I used it I had no idea how to even cut my hair with electric clippers and it came out better than I've ever cut my hair before. I can now cut my hair in the same amount of time it used to take to get it cut at a barber and it'll look great too. Perfect for any man looking to save money from haircuts.
  3122. Works great, many different guard lengths that I like, helps get length just right. Only con is that the guards seem flimsy, will see if they last.
  3123. For the average Mom with kids, especially boys, I recommend strongly getting some clippers and doing this yourself. Clippers will save you time and money. When your kids get old enough, you may teach them how to cut their own hair, as well. You don't have to wait at the hair salon or barber--or follow their hours.<br /><br />I don't think that Wahl makes consumer products in the US anymore; thus, I wonder if parts will remain available in the future. Wahl was better about that than Remington or other consumer-intended mfrs. who use the PRC. I note on the Wahl site that accessories and parts still prove more available than from colleague competitors. More products are being made here again--I hope that Wahl will return to US manufacturing soon.<br /><br />Also, I own another Wahl clipper set (I misplaced this one), the Wahl clipper accessory kit, and a Wahl electric razor. I've tried Remington clippers and something else (cheap and underpowered) from the PRC--that simply won't do. The Remington was OK except that the lever raises up--Wahl doesn't do that. I've given up on the Remington now and use this Wahl again. (I wanted to see Remington's \\"spin\\" on this--really, it's pretty much the same--even the cutters (blades) look the same: Do these all come from the same fabricator?) Wahl clippers are the best obtainable from common consumer sources, in my experience.<br /><br />Taking the plunge and actually doing this oneself is hard at first: It's not a big deal after one gets some experience, though. My first self-cut wasn't bad. I think that many people purchase clippers and end up not using them (including my parents long ago)--they may not make the effort to follow the instructions and obtain experience. It's likely that they scratch their heads--wondering (exactly) what to do--or they have doubts: They give up even before trying. (I guess it's just plain fear.) At some point, if one desires to master this (at this level), one must \\"dive in\\"--trusting the instructions, the product, and its clipper-guides--ultimately trusting oneself. It's not rocket-science--users quite likely will succeed--many others here did, too!<br /><br />I've been doing this for 5yrs.+ now. . What I did first was to get a good large hand mirror and a good floor mirror--I use them in concert with the bathroom mirror. (One likely could get by merely with the hand mirror and bathroom mirror.) I follow the instructions and trust the clipper guides. Then, I rid myself of too-long sideburns and scruff on the back of the neck with the clippers--sans guides. Afterwards, according to the mirrors, I go over the back and ears (carefully) with the included scissors to \\"level\\" them out. Fairly recently, I went down one size with the guides--my hair grows back well. My relatives and ladyfriend think that I do a pretty good job....<br /><br />For the \\"cape,\\" I obtained a cheap sheet set and cut a hole in the fitted sheet--the flat sheet is for the floor (to gather clippings). Afterwards, I shake these out thoroughly into a large trash can and then launder--the lint trap catches the remaining hair. Also, I use a \\"Red\\" exercise chair (a swivel exercise chair)--an office chair is OK, too. (Given I'm at home alone, I go \\"Rambo\\"--why get hair on my clothes anyway?!) After brushing hair from the clippers with the small brush, stowing the set away, and ridding the area of hairs (especially when I let my hair \\"go\\" too long), I shower directly afterwards to shed any smaller hairs left over.<br /><br />I'm now interested in exploring different cuts, techniques, and obtaining some other \\"pro\\" equipment--cape, etc.
  3124. I ordered this so I could cut my own hair ... mine is simple, nothing layered or complicated. All I need is a 4, 3, and 2 guard. But I digress.<br /><br />For the money, this thing is great! It literally pays for it self in 1 or 2 uses, depending on what you typically pay for haircuts. It cuts great, no pulls or tugs on my hair through 3 uses (at the time of this review). The only reason it doesn't get 5 starts in my book is because the packaging is prone to breaking some of the guards. When I got the item, all of the guards and loose pieces were in one bag, which is okay usually, but in this case multiple guards got caught in one another and one was broken from all of that tangle. The guards are not insanely flimsy, but they are not exactly strong either, so I would just say be careful with them and beware when you take the guards out in case they are tangled in one another.<br /><br />But overall, a great product for the price.

  3175. Made in USA<br /><br />This is my first electrical hair cutter. Before this I either use a comb and scissor with a mirror to cut my hair. But it's very risky since it's very easy to cut my own flesh, especially when I'm in a hurry. Moreover, my scissor + comb approach has great difficult cutting my hair even and smooth. With this new electric hair cutter, I was able to cut my hair within a short period of time and it's safe!<br /><br />There are several things which I feel might be helpful:<br />(1) The lubrication oil should always be added to the blade every time I finish my hair cut and clean the hair residue, so that the oil &#34;soaks&#34; the blade to make it sharp and function smoothly next time.<br />(2) Add a few droplets of oil every time I start my new hair cut, so that I can be sure that the blades are lubricated.<br />(3) The holding position of the hand is a bit critical. If I hold it too much in the front, I feel significant vibrations on my hand, which is not nice. So my adjusting my hand location, I hold it a little bit in the back near the stick labels. It might feel not very stable because the front end is heavier, but less vibration :)<br /><br />The last thing is when I received this item, the blue cap with the stick label had fallen off. And the on of the snap-fits in the front was broken. Well, I used the super glue to glue the black cap and the white handle plastic together and they never separate any more!

This I believe happens when the top and bottom portion of the clipper is very slightly misaligned. To avoid this from happening just hold the clipper in the front portion of the body with one hand while you press the button with the other. When I started turning it on this way, it worked perfectly and never had any problems.<br /><br />Definitely a must get!

  3270. I've had one of these for several years. I just bought two more to put on the shelf. I'm retiring a Conair because it is starting to get dull and it's cheaper to just buy new clippers. What I like about this Wahl is that it comes with a 1/16&#34; piece. Most kits stop at 1/8th inch. It is quiet, more quite than some clippers I've had, and doesn't seem to need to be cleaned quite as often as other clippers I've had. I cut my hair and the hair of my two boys. I've been doing so for about 12 years. You do have to make multiple passes with the Wahl but that is no big deal when you save the cost of the clippers with one or two haircuts and then go on to save hundreds before the cutters become too dull to cut well. For the price you're not getting professional quality clippers and attachments, but you're getting clippers and attachments that are quite good for cutting your's and family members hair. Before the Conair I had one other set of clippers. That makes two sets of clippers I've retired. I'm guessing that the Wahl i'm currently using and two new backups I've purchased will together last the rest of my life. I won't have to cut my kid's hair forever, just my own. BTW, on myself I use the 1/16&#34; attachment and use it to cut my hair all the same length. When I first started I used the 1/2', 3/8&#34;, 1/4&#34;, and then the 1/8&#34; (until I got the Wahl with 1/16&#34;) and cut my hair 1/2&#34; in length and then I tapered the back and sides. I've tried using the attachments that are greater than 1/2&#34; on the kids but have had mixed results. I think the 1/2&#34; and smaller attachments work best. If you want hair longer than that I suggest doing a scissor cut and then using the clippers to taper the sides and back if tapering is desired. Lastly, one of my boys has very thick hair. The Conair had a tough time with his hair but this Wahl had no problem at all.

  3373. Must say I was surprised by the performance.
  3374. As usual, after reading mostly good reviews for ithis item here on Amazon, I decided this would be the set of clippers to buy for our needs. I read the bad reviews too, especially noted the ones about hair on the clippers, but figured it must be certain sellers/vendors on Amazon turning around returned used clippers and selling them to another unsuspecting customer. Not willing to take the chance that this might happen to me ordering off of Amazon, I decided to buy it local. Saw it at our neighborhood Target, and also noticed a nice Conair clipper that was about $15 right next to it on the shelf. Both seemed comparable, about the same number of pieces and same type of pieces with just a little variance, and 5 year warranty. Decided to stick with my decision to try the Wahl clippers based on all the good Amazon reviews. First box right up front looked opened, seal broken, so picked out another one that looked nice and properly sealed, and ran home with it.<br /><br />I honestly don't think it's just the sellers/vendors on Amazon, because this one came right off a Target shelf and the packaging looked new and well sealed, not at all like it had been previously opened then resealed. First thing I noticed after opening the package and taking the guard off the clipper is a bunch of tiny black hair all over it. I showed it immediately to my husband, who replied with a disgusted 'eww' right off the bat, which was my immediate reaction as well. Neither of us has black hair, so you can be sure it didn't come from us. I was so upset. I figure it has to be the company that is turning around returned product. If the company wants to do that with a returned product they think is still in working order and still sellable, or they refurbish a non-working unit and resell it, fine. At least have the decency, however, to clean and disinfect the clipper and it's blades before doing so. Paying full price, thinking it's brand new, then have it looking like it was already used before yougot it is a total turn off. This was the first time ever buying clippers in my life, and my first time buying Wahl. Never again. I immediately went back to Target and returned it for a refund, no problems. Even the girl behind the customer service desk at Target said eww when we told her the reason for the return, and apologized, though it was no fault of her own. I bought the Conair instead, opened it and checked it in the car before leaving the Target parking lot this time, and no hair on these clippers. They look clean and brand new. Have yet to test their performance though, but at least they don't look USED out of the box.<br /><br />Update 11/09/12: It has been awhile since this review was written, and just had to add that the Conair clippers worked very well for us.<br /><br />Lillia~ Bob's Wife

  3387. Clippers for hair cuts are difficult to know which ones to buy. For those that HAVE bought clippers, they know the horrors of trying to figure out what is what and goes where and does what. But here is the simple break down on these clippers.<br /><br />1) It is a Wahl. Wahl is a very popular brand of clippers. They are popular for a reason. Reliability.The older clippers get, the more they rust, the more they pull hair, and the less effective the cut is. I had a set of Wahl clippers for more that 10 years while I was in the military. I bought news one because I lost all of the pieces.<br />2) This is a 20 piece PRO kit. store brand clippers have cheap plastic parts that break, they're all the same color, hard to differentiate between what is what, and worst of all, the clippers make weird noises when you turn them on. I have had this particular model for a couple years now. It sound brand new every time I turn it on.<br />3) The color coding really eases the anxiety of trying to decide which head to use for cutting.<br />4) The case this is all contained in, is superb. No cheap locking clip, sturdy handle, and well organized interior to help keep your pieces from getting lost.<br />5) By some chance you loose the instructions, it is permanently printed on the handle of the clippers. This is great for beginners. No need to do the math, or figure out what is what. Pick a length, and match the color. SUPER EASY!<br />6) The instruction manual not only tells you the operation of the clippers, but also tells you how to actually USE these clippers to start cutting hair on day 1. These are the things you get with a PRO kit!<br />7) If you get this on sale,.... buy yourself two or three sets, maybe even four sets. People will want them, and they will &#34;borrow&#34; them. They often do not find their way home. So give them as gifts, and keep your clippers!

  3446. For the price, this Wahl Haircutter and kit cannot be beat.<br /><br />It does take a while to become hot, but not hot to touch around the latch area. If you have used haircutters before, you know that you should power it off after prolonged use, give it a minute, and power it up to use it again.<br /><br />This haircutter is of high-quality. Wahl does a great job. I have used their lower tier products ranging from $8-12 and they are still working. This is definitely a cut above those lower end haircutters that I have used from Wahl even though the price range is not very far off.<br /><br />Do not be discouraged to purchase this excellent product because of the price. It has a good weight to it, and you can feel that it is of quality material from the surface to the internal motor that powers it inside. Wahl did not cut corners with this one.<br /><br />I feel obligated to send them more money for this product. It is a steal.<br /><br />It comes with a neat plastic case with a handle that stores the haircutter and all 20 pieces of hair clips. It even comes with TAPER clips! One for the left side and one for the right side. It works wonderfully.<br /><br />Overall, it cuts well like any good to great haircutter.<br /><br />I highly, HIGHLY recommend it. Excellent value.

  3501. What a return on investment! I've been using this for the last year and a half and am able to do a great job cutting my own hair. It took a few times before I got the hang of it, but the results were never disastrous. Now I get a haircut that's probably 90% as good as my barber/stylist used to do. Not once has anyone made fun of my haircut and I've even received compliments on it a couple of times.<br /><br />Useful tips - the best time to use this is right after you've washed your hair. Towel dry your hair, then blow dry it if necessary to 'fluff it up' so your hair is standing out from your scalp. This lets the cutter give the most even, consistent results. If your hair is matted down, or oily the results will be uneven. Don't rush, especially the first few times. Think about how your barber/stylist gives you a haircut and basically try and replicate those steps.
  3502. This is my first Wahl product. I read all the reviews before buying it as it was less than $20 on amazon when I purchased it. Good price but after using it to cut my son's thick hair, here's what I think;<br /><br />The clipper feels heavy. It will take some getting used to. I had a similar conair clipper that, after a while, became a problem for my wrist due to the weight. The most recent clipper I had before this was a conair light-weight clipper that was more comfortable to work with, for me.<br /><br />The pieces are very flimsy plastic. I was afraid they might unlock when I was cutting my son's hair or break, but it didn't. It will be a concern, though, every time I cut.<br /><br />One or two of the pieces weren't numbered like the others, as another reviewer pointed out.<br /><br />The wire is standard length as most clippers I have used.<br /><br />Very sharp and cut very well.Overall, it's a keeper.

  3553. This is a gem of a purchase; you can't beat the price.<br /><br />PROS<br />1) price<br />2) has all the equipment and guards that you could want for grooming (I use it to trim a beard and keep my face looking less grotesque than it otherwise would), plus they give you some blade lubricant so you can make sure you're taking good care of it.<br />3) hard shell carrying/storage case keeps it all nicely together and makes traveling with it easier<br /><br />CONS<br />1) In the beginning, this this would pluck an occasional hair out instead of cutting it. Something about the new blades, I think. This made for a bit of an uncomfortable first few weeks. The problem has subsided, however, and now I don't have to fear that I am putting an Epilady to my face.
  3554. Years cutting hair: 15<br />Clippers used: 6 (4 brands)<br />Best so far: this one, my first Wahl.<br />Its &#34;heavy, powerful motor&#34; other reviews rave about uses only 9 watts, but never even changes sound in thick areas, and it clips every hair. I've had others that used 12 watts, but slowed down on every pass, missing hairs all over the place. I guess it's all in the blade.<br /><br />Other blades have overheated and burned me, pulled hair, pinched skin, misaligned mid-haircut, clogged easily, stopped completely, needed re-oiled mid-haircut, broken themselves on my hair, and cut so unevenly that my hair looked cat-chewed. Cheap, foreign-labor pieces of junk! Grrr! Don't do it!<br /><br />Wahl, however, prides themselves on their blade quality, and it shows. I cannot emphasize this enough! Night and day difference for thick hair!<br /><br />This is the cheap Wahl model, and I may upgrade later, but it's still got it where it counts. I strongly recommend this kit (plus a hand mirror or good partner for the back) for anyone starting out, or trying Wahl after horrible disappointment in cheap clippers. You won't regret it!

  3600. My Wahl clipper was delivered in three days on a free shipping order.My experiences have always been very satisfactory with Amazon.<br /><br />This review is the perception of a man in his mid-eighties, limited with the effects of a stroke with tremors and poor peripheral and depth perception vision. Because of these challenges, I purchased this product with trepidation, especially after reading the one and two star ratings. However after weighing against the five star ratings, I concluded that many of the poor ratings appear to be over exaggerated.My initial experience is positive and perhaps I should have entitled this review \\"IF I CAN DO IT, YOU CAN DO IT BETTER!\\"<br /><br />Step one: To avoid the clutter of attachments, I removed the guide combs I will not be using and left only those I expect to use which will probably be reduced further. I then oiled the blade before using, despite the manufacturer's claim of having done so, as the kit may have been in stock for a lengthy period which might have caused drying. Unfortunately, because of my tremors I over-oiled and hope this may not harm the motor.I compared the oil with mineral oil which I use on my electric shaver and find no difference plus I have read several reviews where the same conclusion was reached with no negative effect.<br /><br />Step two: The noise level doesn't exceed the clippers used by most barbers and is not in the least bit annoying. The weight is heavier than I would like but should not be a problem for most users (perhaps I should have chosen the \\"Peanut\\" model, but it is manageable.) I felt anxious as I started cutting, especially without the benefit of a rear view mirror and felt that perhaps I made a mistake in trying to cut my own hair, but when I was through and asked for my wife's opinion, she stated the result was better than the usual cuts I get from barbers.<br /><br />I feel grateful for my success and sure that future cuts will be done in half the time with even better results.I highly recommend this hair clipper, based on price and results. It deserves 5 stars but I rated it 4 solely for its weight and my lack of dexterity. After a few more cuts, I will update my experience.<br /><br />Update: 7/31/13<br /><br />I Totally forgot to update sooner, but was reminded by a commenter.Unfortunately. old age and memory are not very compatible.<br /><br />It is almost a year since my purchase of this product and I remain very satisfied with my choice. I do not labor long in the trimming process, but work within the limited dexterity and visual challenges mentioned in my initial review. I use a #2 comb on my nape and the surrounding areas of my ears, then change to a #3 comb to taper below the top of my scalp which is very sparse and kept in a oomb-over fashion. This process takes less than five minutes and results in a neat trim appearance.<br /><br />Admittedly,if I was younger and going to business and socializing, I would take more time and care, or ask for my wife's assistance.I'm just glad that I didn't heed the one star reviewers. This trimmer is powerful and solidly built and does not sound loud at all. The combs are sturdy. All in all, it is an excellent choice at a bargain price.
  3601. VERY nice product. If you trying to figure out if this like the ones they use at the salons and Barbers the answer is yes. It has a very good hum to it and it doesn't pull your hair like many of the cheap ones. I AM SATISFIED!

  3613. I think this is a great product for the price. I have used it about six times and after a few got my hair cut down to a pretty reliable routine. Saves time too, I can have my hair cut and clean up in way less time that it wold take go to barber.<br /><br />I read some reviews before I bought and I think some of the low ratings are due to user error. Some people complained about the shaver losing power and then not working at all. There is an adjustment screw that adjusts low to high. Too high and you get a loud buzzing and harsh vibration. Too low and no power. Because of the mechanical motion I think the screw setting drifts overtime or maybe there is variation at electrical outlet. In any case, it is very simple fix, adjust the screw setting. Product instructions on this point are clear.

The one thing I noticed right away was how powerful the motor is.<br /><br /> I usually cut my hair very low almost bald and if there is sweat on my head the other machines would have a difficult time cutting it but with this clipper it had no problem cutting my damp hair. The blade is also of better quality and material. After adjusting the blade and setting it to its lowest setting, the clipper can cut my hair almost bald not a complete zero but close. You might be able to use it to tape if you have hair/high fade, but it you have a low fade you will need a separate trimmer for tapping.

  3669. Excellent set of hair clippers. Cut smoothly and with the various combs most haircuts (especially for men) are pretty effortless. So usually after about 2-3 years of use cutting two people's hair once a month, the cord will short out at the base. The cord can be fixed, but to be honest it with about 48-72 haircuts before the cord fails, it's easier to just buy another unit for the low price. This is my third clipper (same one) in ten years of use. I will keep buying them every few years...new blades, new motor, new cord, near scissors,etc for another 70 haircuts.

Until the blade got dull, I saw this Wahl 79300-400 on Amazon with high rating on it. I decided to give it a try. After 5 cuts into my son's hair, I had to put it down and used my old Wahl Designer one, even though the blade got really dull. I am returning this. it doesn't say clearly where it was made but I wouldn't be surprise that it's made in China. Spend $30 more or so for the pro series, it will be much worth it. Cons: 1) It chews hair, doesn't cut well. 2) The blade is bigger compare to Wahl Designer. the guides that came with this one can be easily mounted on to the Designer; a slightly push would snap on. But, It is really hardly mount on this one, You have to stress the small end plastic piece out and push hard to mount it, no it doesn't snap. 3) The switch is too small, it hard to turn on or off, it looks very cheap and flimsy, especially the guides are made from cheap soft plastic. Pros: NONE
  3692. Decent razor that gets the job done. I was impressed with the sheer number of attachments that came with it. Unless you want your hair to stay really long, this set will probably last you a while and you won't need extra pieces.
  3693. Worked well til it was dropped in a sink once. Empty sink, 2 foot drop max. Won't work & can't get any response from Wahl<br /><br />If you're confident that you or anyone else with access to it will never drop it, then it's probably a good buy. Otherwise I'd buy a more reliable product or an equally speciously made product from a company that will at least respond to email
  3694. Excellent product for the money. I have had this since it came out and we use it frequently. I am impressed with the overall design, much easier to hold than others and so much easier to use. My 15 year old cuts his own hair with this and always does a great job. It cuts as close or as far away as you want and really have had no issues with dull blades or anything of the sort. I think this is the best buy for your money.
  3695. No major concerns. Guards all good, arrived in one piece and all.<br />However, it came with a pair of scissors, that were WAY too blunt. And since I actually already have a pair of scissors for cutting hair, it's not much of a problem.
  3696. arrived on timeas described exceptional gift
  3697. I like the color system with the guards. As someone who does haircuts at home and doesn't have as much space to operate,store and organize as a barber does in a shop, it really makes it easy/quick to find the guards. I really like how the 1 guard cut. A nice smooth cut. I use the 1/16th a lot with my clippers. I didn't find this guard hit as close as I wanted it to, regardless of whether I open or closed the blade. The guards are a nice, sturdy plastic which I like. I'm somewhat meticulous when I cut my hair, so they take long. The clipper got a little hot but not much after about 25 min. Overall, I'm satisfied with my purchase, especially given the price. It's not a set of Oster 76s but it's better than a cheap set of Conair clippers and I paid about the same price.
  3698. My husbands hair grows fast and he just shaves it anyway since he wears a hardhat at times, $20. bucks gets old fast for a 5 minute head shave. I don't typically use them as I've cut hair enough now that I don't need them, but tried them and they work great. His hair is very thick and heavy, it cuts right through with no problem.

  3734. I bought these because I sometimes get lazy with shaving my head and the clippers that pop out of my Norelco's back have a hard time with my thick hair if I let it grow more than four or five days. These clippers are surprisingly well made given their price range and while the plastic portion of the casing feels a bit flimsy the metal underside seems like it could take a beating. It managed to sheer through two months worth of my hair without too much of a struggle, and the shave was decently close to boot. Unless these suddenly give out within my next couple of shaves I'm pretty darn satisfied. I did have one minor hiccup with these though, the first set I got had clippers that were pretty clearly used, covered in greasy fingerprints with bits of hair stuck between the teeth. A quick e-mail to Amazon and they had a brand new set on my doorstep by the next afternoon and the second set was perfect. The only thing keeping this review from being five stars is the plastic upper casing, but for $18 I dare you to find a sturdier set of clippers.

  3745. We bought this clipper at Walmart for about the same price as it is listed on Amazon.<br /><br />As others have mentioned, the packaging is bad; and when we first opened it up out of the box, one of the clipper attachments was broken. We immediately exchanged it for a new one.<br /><br />The motor works as expected, but after putting it away and storing the clippers in the case (as is expected), we opened it up again to find another attachment broken. I believe this is more an issue with the thin plastic walls than it is with the case; you can probably break the tongs off with less than 1 pound of force at the end of the tine. That is completely unacceptable, and you would expect to see it survive basic handling.<br /><br />I am surprised that Wahl is cost cutting on such a basic element. Here's an idea; instead of thinning the walls of the plastic to save a quarter penny/each, how about eliminating one attachment altogether, and make it more durable. A single tine failure is equivalent to the entire set failing, unless you are just shearing sheep.<br /><br />Pass on this one.

  3748. Straight out of the box, these clippers feel heavy-duty and durable. Also included are a nice pair of scissors and cleaning oil and brush, along with a handy haircutting guide containing good instructions and photos. It really is everything you need, all in one neat little case! The clippers, while heavier than I was expecting, were easy to use and simple to adjust to desired length. Even for someone like me who had never cut hair before, my husband came out looking just as good as if he went to the local chain salon, maybe even better. I can't say enough about what an exceptional value this kit is... At $22.00, it paid for itself in just one haircut. Hubby is also using the clippers to groom his beard, and they work wonderfully.   3810. Fantastic trimmer - glad I trusted the reviews. Feels well made, heavy in the hand and plenty of power for thick hair, etc. I've been using this for about a year (I cut my own hair) and it was completely worth the price of entry. Don't waste your time on the Walmart junk that will die in a few months.
  3811. I've never owned a clipper or haircutting kit before. My father in the early '50s use to cut my hair and my brothers hair with clippers which was, at the time, typical. When I received the &#34;Wahl 79300-400&#34; kit, it seemed very sturdy and well constructed. I liked the the color coded combs and well written instructions. So, what did I do? I handed it to my 18 year old daughter, who had never cut hair in her life, and said &#34;Give me a haircut.&#34; The results were great! The clippers worked without a hitch and I received compliments at work of what a great haircut I have. I would recommend these clippers/kit to anyone just beginning to give haircuts.
  3812. I love Wahl hair trimmers so much I have two of the same models (purchased second one because I needed a haircut while on vacation and it was cheaper to buy another set than to go to most barbers in NYC). for simple cuts like mine, its easy, safe and fun, and the shortest setting is nearly a shave, but so much safer that we cut our baby's hair with it.<br /><br />why Wahl vs other brands? I have had others and they just aren't as powerful or sturdy. Wahl powers through any minor tangles of your hair while other brands get painfully caught in the tangle. Wahl also lasts longer as it has more metal components (apparent in the weight and heft of Wahl). cheaper brands save you only a few dollars off trhis model. you make up the difference in your first use. my first Wahl unit has lasted 4 years and still going strong. the unit I just purchased and which I am reviewing has one shorter setting piece than prior models and slightly quieter, otherwise identical.<br /><br />I don't see any meaningful functional difference between Wahl entry models vs their more expensive models. they all cut well and the differences seem mostly cosmetic.<br /><br />now for a few warnings. if you are going to cut your hair (rather than merely trim sideburns or beard), I would stay away from battery operated models which I have found to be underpowered for hair. also, for this model you will need an extension cord. and I wiah Wahl would also include a compact mirror to check the back.
  3813. Nice clipper set at an exceptional; price! My old Wahl was about worn out and this set was less than the cost of repairing the old one. In addition I now have a full set of all the blade guides I have lost over the years.

  3848. This is a great set from Wahl!<br />Over the years (more than 30 years) I have used sets like this from many vendors (including Conair, GE, and others) but none ever compare to the Wahl. The combination of the carbon steel cutting head and a motor large enough to power it is just excellent. But this set has two more nice touches, the heavy duty plastic case is actually useful, and the brightly colored combs virtually ensure that you can't make a mistake by inadvertently selecting the wrong one. All of the combs look pretty much the same anyway, and when the only differentiation is a size noted in black raised numerals on the already black comb, well ... mistakes will happen, and you'll wind up going into work with a much too short haircut.<br />So step up to the Wahl. At this price you really can't go wrong.

  3852. When I first got this product it seemed to work great, however after having only had it for about 6 months, it's already broken. I'm not sure what the problem is, but the on and off switch no longer works properly. When flipping the switch it's like I had to hover it between off and on in just the right location to make it work, and even then it eventually just gave out and the switch wouldn't even move.<br /><br />They also don't use stainless steel so the metal blades rust. I noticed this almost immediately. One time, because of this, after turning it on, the blades seized up and wouldn't work. After moving the height adjustment switch (which moves the blades), all of the rust broke off and it started to work again...I mean what the hell!?<br /><br />This product is cheap but you get what you pay for.

  3864. When I received this wall kit I took it out of the box and the top cover kept falling off the clippers every time I held it or used it.<br />I had to put a rubber band around it to hold it together.<br />Why: in manufacturing they forgot to put two small retainer screws in the retainer screw holes on the back side. The holes are there, the screw receptacles are there, but no screws.<br />They were missed in both Wahl's manufacturing process and in their quality control inspection.<br /><br />This is the second Wahl product that has been devoid of quality control that I have received and used.<br /><br />I do not think the Wahl company has an effective quality control function within their overseas low-pay suppliers.<br />Price was excellent, but apparently not high enough to actually control quality, appearance was good, but where is the quality control in this company?<br />I now have to take my time to go find two small screws and finish their missed manufacturing job. They need to put on their product descriptions: PRODUCT MAY NOT BE FULLY MANUFACTURED OR INSPECTED BEFORE SHIPPING.<br />At least then we would know that we are paying less to get less and my have to finish the manufacturing job.<br /><br />I do not know how others define incompetent but this would seem to be one way.<br />On the performance side, once you put a rubber band around the handle to hold it together, it seems to cut well.

  4028. Well, I thought the color system would be awesome. It's OK. Old dogs, new tricks, etc. As for the clippers themselves, they are OK. Very average in terms of form and function. If you want some cheap, essentially disposable clippers, then these will do the trick. Biggest problem is the case. Some genius decided to make a case so tiny that the clippers can only fit inside if you turn them just so, run the cord through the handle of the case, and then hold it all in place while you latch it. Nevermind the fact that the attachments all have to be perfectly interlocked and arranged to even reach that step, and there is absolutely no room for a single extra accessory--like a pair of scissors, maybe? This is the kind of thing where you hope someone was like &#34;Hey, let's make this case more efficient so it will fit in the drawer easier.&#34; Instead, I can just hear some up-and-comer saying &#34;Hey guys, I just figured out how to make $0.08 more profit on the case!&#34;

I did that, but I'm still stuck with the &#34;ledge&#34; on the bottom AND another &#34;line&#34; at the point where I went &#34;out&#34; away from his head. I did it very gradually, but his hair is such that it accentuates every cut. I'll have to go back to scissors cut, which doesn't solve the extreme bottom of back neck issue, but at least I won't have the line across the mid-back of his head.   4074. Perfect clipper for the aspiring at home barber. I am the guy that used to wait months so my hair would grow out before cutting it short so I would get value out of my haircut. This set is priced right for someone like me who has never cut hair before and comes with most of the necessary tools. It comes with many guides even a behind the ear guide, comb, small bottle of blade oil, and a carrying case. For less than $20 I couldn't ask for more.<br /><br />Some things I would recommend getting would be hair clips if your hair is longer and you don't want to cut it by accident and a handheld mirror. Also be careful about evening the neckline as that was rather difficult for me, I used something to basically make a straight line across and cut up to it, perhaps in the future when my spacial skills while looking through a mirror improve I will be able to do it freehand. It takes a lot of practice but gets easier. First few times just cut very slowly especially if you are on a short setting, I went without a guide to cut my sideburns and ended up cutting a little bit too high by accident! Watch some videos and just go for it, you will never be ready the first time because you've never done it before and that is part of the process. After just one cut you already get the feel for it and are ready to do it better next time.<br /><br />This is a cheap option to try out cutting your own hair at home. If you really mess up then you can just buzz it or go to your normal stylist to fix it. Not a big risk purchase here, low investment but potential high reward.
  4075. Unable to use product in Australia unless I purchase a power converter (120v to 240v). While this could be considered a &#34;rookie error&#34; on my behalf, perhaps some sort of warning about electrical appliances operating on a different voltage system would be appropriate. No issues with the delivery system tho...outstanding service, product was well packaged, and correctly addressed, and arrived on time, I was also able to track my delivery throughout.<br />Cheers,<br />Shawn Brown.

The Wahl was one of the first that popped up and wow for that price I thought even if I could just get two decent haircuts out of it before it dies it will have paid for itself.<br /><br />Long story short I have been cutting my hair with it usually once every two weeks and the results are great. The clippers power through just about anything quickly. They don't snag or pull my hair. I use them for both my beard and head now. I like to keep my hair pretty short or &#34;high and tight&#34; as it were. I can now do it whenever I feel like it and since I've been doing it I've gotten faster and more proficient.<br /><br />So if you aren't afraid of it or someone else using it on you then give it a shot. I have saved over a hundred dollars plus gas and time in trips to my barber by this point. If it dies I will purchase another but I don't see that happening anytime soon. The thing feels solid and comfortable like I would think a full on professional set would.

  4236. For the price...this is an excellent bargain!<br /><br />I had no problems with it at all. It's not the quietest...but not the loudest either. It worked pretty well and didn't pull a the hair. I would prefer a higher quality cutting guides, but these were fine.<br /><br />You can buy similar kits at local stores (Walmart, Kmart, Walgreens, etc) for the same price...but trust me...they are NOT as good of quality. Those I've bought locally have very cheap accessories...and are much louder.<br /><br />These are not professional quality. If you are going to use it daily, I'd recommend paying a little more for a higher quality clipper...but for occasional use to do a quick trim or clean up, these are perfect.<br /><br />For the guys -- if you are going to use these \\"other places\\" besides the head...be careful! Trimming chest and arms/legs are fine...but \\"other places\\" be careful ... it's not designed for that and will do bad things to you (if you catch my drift). If you need something for \\"other places\\"...invest in a Norelco Body Groomer (costs a little more)...but well worth it!

  4399. I purchased this and it has worked great so far. The oil included is enough to run it for the foreseeable future, but the combs feel a little cheap. They are definitely made of a softer plastic than barbers ones. The scissors are sharp, but aren't the kind you can sharpen when they dull. The instructions should say that you should only use the left and right ear faders when getting a cut at a length of 3 or below. I ended up with an awkward one that made me look like a marine cadet for a couple weeks. It will cut all the hair you want it to, but be gentle if you need to cut through a lot of thick hair at once. Everything looks like it should and the loudness is really about the same as the professional ones. Buying from this seller is giving you a discount of a few dollars even over Walmart, but there are some cheaper cutters that you can find even in your local department stores that give the same quality if you don't use them every week.

  4407. This is a review that truly only time will tell. This product is replacing another set of Wahl clippers that had lasted over 15 years, and survived four deployments to Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Iraq and Afghanistan - an outstanding pair of hair clippers. Out of the box the new clippers have the same solid feel; however, the blade adjustment bar seems to be less sturdy. This set of clippers use the same blades as the old set so the cut quality is the same and the Wahl blades last forever. I had just changed out blades in my old clippers just before they decided to die. That set of blades had lasted through all the dust, dirt and sand of over 44 months in SW Asia plus use every 10-14 days over 15 years. The kit contains a few more combs than my old one, which is nice especially when using for my kids hair. The case is cheap plastic and I don't expect the latch to last long, so once it breaks the set will go into the dopp bag that I used for my old set. For now, no complaints and if they last as long as their predicessor did then I will have had two outstanding sets of Wahl hair-clippers.

The pain didn't go away, and the barbs were small enough that they were barely visible to the naked eye. I had to use a jeweler's loop and tweezers to get them out. Under magnification, they were clearly metal barbs lodged in my skin. I'm just glad they didn't go deep enough to get completely underneath. Consider this your warning. I don't know if Wahl had a bad manufacturing batch, or if this kind of quality is the norm, but it has certainly turned me away as a customer.<br /><br />Aside from the metal barbs, my impression was poor in the couple minutes I used it. I have used a handful of this type of razor and this one doesn't shave quite as close as others have.<br /><br />While I wish it offered a closer shave, it is a bit safer than ones that do shave closer.
